Seuran alustava perustamiskokous pidettiin Vaasassa kev√§√§ll√§ 1906.     Karjalainen heimoviikonloppu kokoaa vuosittain toistasataa karjalaisjuurista ja karjalaisuudesta kiinnostunutta yhteen. Perjantaina kokoonnutaan kaupungin vastaanotolle. Sunnuntaina kiinnitet√§√§n muistolaatta alustavan perustamiskokouksen muistoksi, nautitaan heimomurkinasta ja p√§√§juhlan monipuolisesta kulttuuriohjelmasta. Viikonlopun tapahtumat ovat avoimia kaikille karjalaisuudesta kiinnostuneille.   Karjalan Sivistysseura toimii it√§karjalaisen kulttuurin, kielen ja perinteen vaalimiseksi Suomessa ja Ven√§j√§n puolella. Tavoitteeksi asetettiin Vienan henkisen ja aineellisen tilan kohentaminen. Liiton nimi muutettiin vuonna 1917 Karjalan Sivistysseuraksi. Kokko is a Finnish name to bonfire but it also meant an eagle. To lit bonfires is originally a custom of eastern culture in Finland. Nowadays habit has spread over the whole country. They were usually built on open hills, shores or floating rafts. In Karelia people used to built tall tower bonfires. Each girl would choose one of the tall upright poles for herself and watch how it burns. If it burnt entirely, it was a sign of her getting married in that year. Future events have traditionally been predicted from the bonfire¬¥s sparks, for example the coming harvest could be foretold from the volume of sparks.

Miten karjalan kieli on vaikuttan suomen kieleh. (–ö–∞–∫ –∫–∞—Ä–µ–ª—å—Å–∫–∏–π —è–∑—ã–∫ –ø–æ–≤–ª–∏—è–ª –Ω–∞ —Ñ–∏–Ω—Å–∫–∏–π).  THE FINNO-UGRIC WORLD Hungarian National Organisation of the World Congress of Finno.Ugric Peoples: BUDAPEST, 2004   Old Finnish literature was based on the western dialects of Finnish. A western literary norm was about to emerge in Turku in the 16th century, the dominance of which was preserved throughout the Swedish rule in Finland. Early Modern Finnish saw a struggle between the Finnish dialects. The fact that folk poetry has been collected in the eastern area of Finland supported the eastern dialects¬® claim to pride of place in the Finnish literary language. The Finnish literary standard today, however, includes elements from the grammar and the vocabulary of both western and eastern dialects. Now that the two dialects have been "levelled", the speaker of literary Finnish can understand Karelian as well as, to some degree, Estonian and Ingrian.

Ei vain karjalaisie ahissettu, hyvin koski muillesuomalais-ugrilaisille kansoille, niile saamelaisilleki  (–ù–µ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –∫–∞—Ä–µ–ª–æ–≤ –ø—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Å–Ω—è–ª–∏, –ø–æ—Ä—è–¥–∫–æ–º –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–ª–æ—Å—å –∏ –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–º —Ñ–∏–Ω–Ω–æ-—É–≥–æ—Ä—Å–∫–∏–º –Ω–∞—Ä–æ–¥–∞–º, —Ç–µ–º –∂–µ —Å–∞–∞–º–∞–º)  THE FINNO-UGRIC WORLD, Budapest, 2004  In Norway a process on Norwegianisation was practised quite aggressively at the end of the 19th century when the first laws promoting assimilation were introduced- An influx of settlers targeted the Sami heartlands and new Norwegian settlements were established. From 1905 onwards it was forbidden to sell land to anyone who did not have a Norwegian name or could not speak Norwegian. Regulations in the sphere of education to assimilate the Sami into the majority were in force until the end of World War II. The assimilation policy of the Finnish state concerning the Sami was not as hostile as in the neighbouring Scandinavian countries.  The status of the Sami improved considerably in Finland and in the Scandinavian countries after World War II, and their sense on national identity has strengthened from the 1960s on. During 1950-51 a common literary language was created for the Sami of Norway and Sweden.
